content: Puzzling. I have used Thunderbird for two decades and word wrap has always worked. Possibly knowing more about your settings may prove helpful. Word wrap is the default, so I'm surprised that it isn't working for you.
creator: davidsk

content:
re :Microsoft Outlook composition is close to that of Microsoft Word.

There is a common theme here - Microsoft own both and they charge users for their product, so have plenty of resources to create complex programs.

Thunderbird does not have those resources to create complex Word Processing programs and they are not related to eg: OpenOffice or LibreOffice or anything developed by Microsoft etc.

I've always found Thunderbird to be perfectly ok when it comes to composing emails and have no issues regarding Word Wrap. Thunderbird composing is designed in such a way that it should be able to be read by various OS and by people with various reading requirements and set up. Not everyone has the same fonts nor uses the same font sizes. So keeping it simple is actually a massive benefit. Believe it or not, the email you compose will look different on other peoples screens. Most of the code Microsoft insert into emails is just bloat and alot of it cannot be read by anything that's not Microsoft. It may look good to the composer using Outlook, but that doesn't mean the recipient is seeing the same.

Check settings and let us know what you are currently set up to use.

  • Settings > General
  • Scroll to bottom
  • Click on 'Config Editor'
  • In top search type: wrap
  • Post an image showing what you see.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Hello David, thanks for your quick feedback. If you don't understand the problem, it will be impossible to get some tips for the investigations. . . Sorry for the wrong description... I'll try to explain it better: The weird behaviour is that the e-mails loaded into the local Thunderbird installation are deleted from the server area, without any manual action of the receiver. The right way should be "loading messages" only and "deleting it only when the receiver deletes it manually from the the local inbox". The automatic deletion of e-mails from the server area is a possible settings of the POP communication. But the settings are defined with IMAP link. It that more clear in this way? Best regards, Bernard
creator: Bernye00

content: The POP and IMAP accounts work independently, so let's focus on POP. The normal setting is to download the message and automatically delete from server. That appears to be what you are experiencing. If you do not want the messages deleted, you can adjust the setting at the account's server setting to keep on server until deleted. You should also review the 'disk space' setting.

content: There is always the possibility of a bug in software getting into a release, but 115.8 is quite stable. However, in using any software product, the user needs to take ownership of any data that may be affected. My suggestion is to do a profile backup periodically and always before a major update. Most errors of substance occur when anti-virus software interrupts Thunderbird updates. Managing one's anti-virus software is an important aspect.
creator: davidsk

content: The login screens are standard for OAuth2 authentication, but if you have to enter your address manually, it usually means you haven't accepted cookies in TB (not Firefox) Settings/Privacy & Security.

content: Well, if it is a POP account, All messages still on the server would be downloaded again because Thunderbird doesn't know you did this before. If this is an IMAP account, the messages were never deleted and now visible again. If this is a POP account , the prior setup may have specified to leave on server. Those are just guesses, but would relate to the issue as described. One possible way to delete old messages is to create a filter and delete messages older than a specific date.

content: This is new to me. Thunderbird keeps nothing of what users do. You may have kept a copy in sent folder, which should have the header records showing to whom and when the message was sent. You could contact your email provider, but I am not aware that they keep such detailed information.
creator: davidsk

content:
Have you set up your Account Settings > Junk Settings for each mail account? Have you trained Thunderbird so it knows examples of what is Junk and what is not junk?

Set up each mail account junk controls: In 'Account Settings'

  • Select 'Junk Settings' for the mail account.
  • Select 'Enable adaptive junk mail controls for this account'
  • Select all necessary address books to act as a whitelist.
  • If required - I personally do not use this - select 'Trust junk mail headers set by eg: Spamassassin' - Do not select it if not sure.
  • Select 'Move new junk messages to';

If you are using a POP mail account:

  • Select 'Junk folder on' and choose the mail account

If using IMAP mail account:

  • Select 'Other' and choose the server subscribed folder name eg: 'Spam on account email address'

Set up the default junk mail settings:

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • scroll to 'Junk' section
  • Select: 'When I mark messages as junk'
  • Select 'Move them to the accounts junk folder'
  • select 'Enable adaptive junk filter logging'

How to train the junk filter can be found here:

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages#w_training-the-junk-filter

Please note it is just as important to train what is junk and what is not junk. It can take a couple of weeks to really get the junk controls working well. It improves as it learns.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Is this an IMAP account? If so, mass processes can be problematic. My suggestion is to create filters for the major spammers, as that causes the detritus to be destroyed as it comes in, minimizing the need for massive deletes. My personal preference is the separate product, mailwasher, which is free for one account. I start it first thing in the morning and it deletes spammers immediately and I can add to the list of known spammers and know it's a one-time thing to do. But filters do the same thing; just set them up for the main ones, and life gets better. this also lets you delete them, not just move to trash.
creator: davidsk

content: Setting up a new Thunderbird and training the spam filter is like having a new child: the training all begins again from scratch. This URL may help: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages the filter gets smarter the more you identify the good and the bad. Good luck.
creator: davidsk
